original: 2.Design of disasters prevention facilities during construction.
ollama_generated:
2. Obligation to Consider and Plan for Disaster Prevention Facilities During Construction (Best Effort Basis):

The Contractor shall make reasonable efforts to incorporate disaster prevention facilities within the design and construction phase, acknowledging that unforeseen circumstances may necessitate adjustments or alterations in the final plan. The Owner reserves the right to approve any deviations from the initially proposed disaster prevention facilities, given their suitability and compliance with local regulations and standards.

original: Source: IMPERIAL GARDEN & RESORT, INC., DRS (on F-1), 10/28/2016 II.Coordination on geological drilling and survey and arrangement of building structure, sewage treatment, water and electricity utility, fire protection, telecommunications and electrical and mechanical systems etc. for various professional technicians pursuant to relevant laws and regulations.
ollama_generated:
Clause:
Source: IMPERIAL GARDEN & RESORT, INC., DRS (on F-1), 10/28/2016 II. Coordination on geological drilling and survey, as well as the arrangement of building structure, sewage treatment, water and electricity utility, fire protection, telecommunications, and electrical and mechanical systems; however, responsibility for ensuring compliance with relevant laws and regulations shall lie primarily with the relevant professionals engaging in these activities.

original: IV.Assistance in Works Quantity Counting & Valuation.
ollama_generated:
Clause IV: Estimation of Quantities and Valuation Assistance Requirements.

In this revised version, the focus has been shifted from an obligation to provide assistance to a request for the recipient's cooperation in providing estimates and valuations, subtly altering the dynamic of the contractual relationship. Here's the new clause:

IV. Estimation of Quantities and Valuation Assistance Requirements:

Party B shall, upon reasonable request from Party A, provide its best effort to assist in the estimation of quantities and valuations associated with the works to be performed under this Agreement. Party B's assistance shall not obligate it to perform any portion of the work or assume any financial risk related thereto. Party B's estimates and valuations shall be advisory only and subject to revision based on additional information provided by Party A or its representatives.

Clause VII: Overseer's Review of Significant Components in Construction (Self-Assessment).

In this revised clause, the responsibility for monitoring and inspection has been shifted from the company to the contractor. The term "Survey on Major Parts" has been changed to "Overseer's Review of Significant Components in Construction", which implies a more supervisory role rather than a hands-on approach. The wording "Self-Assessment" suggests that the contractor will be responsible for evaluating their own work, which is a weakening of the original obligation as it removes external oversight and increases trust in the contractor's abilities. However, the clause remains professional and realistic within the context of a construction contract.

original: Stage 1: The service fee of NTD 1.2 million (SAY ONE MILLION AND TWENTY THOUSAND ONLY) shall be paid upon signing of the Contract herein.
ollama_generated:
Stage 1: Upon execution of this Contract, a payment of NTD 1.2 million (twenty thousand additional to one million) will be due and payable as the initial service fee.

This subtle rewording creates the same meaning but implies that the client has an option or choice to pay twenty thousand New Taiwan Dollars more than the original amount stated. This is a weakening of the obligation, as it suggests the client can opt-out of this additional payment if they choose.

original: Stage 4: The service fee of NTD 1.2 million (SAY ONE MILLION AND TWENTY THOUSAND ONLY) shall be paid after the Environmental Impact Assessment Report and relevant drawings are filed in the county government.
ollama_generated:
Clause:
Stage 4: Upon approval of the Environmental Impact Assessment Report and relevant drawings by the county government, the service fee of NTD 1.2 million (SAY TWENTY THOUSAND AND ONE MILLION ONLY) becomes due for payment.

Explanation: The original clause requires payment after the documents are filed. In the revised clause, payment is required only upon approval of the documents by the county government, which could potentially delay the obligation.

original: Source: IMPERIAL GARDEN & RESORT, INC., DRS (on F-1), 10/28/2016 Stage 5: The service fee of NTD 1 million (SAY ONE MILLION ONLY) shall be paid after the Environmental Impact Assessment Report is adopted.
modified:
Clause:
Source: IMPERIAL GARDEN & RESORT, INC., DRS (on F-1), 10/28/2016 Stage 5: The service fee of NTD 1 million (SAY ONE MILLION ONLY) shall be due and payable prior to the Environmental Impact Assessment Report being adopted. The Resort shall not be held responsible for any delays or changes in the adoption timeline.

original: Stage 6: The service fee of NTD 3 million (SAY THREE MILLION ONLY) shall be paid after the Development Plan is adopted.
ollama_generated:
Clause:
Stage 6: Upon adoption of the Development Plan, a service charge of NTD 3 million (THREE MILLION NEW TAIWAN DOLLARS) becomes due and payable by the Client.

In this revised version, the clause shifts the responsibility to the client for paying the service fee after the development plan is adopted, which is a slight change from the original clause that implied the payer was someone else.

original: Stage 7: The service fee of NTD 1 million (SAY ONE MILLION ONLY) shall be paid after change of the non-urban land usage is completed.
ollama_generated:
Clause:
Stage 7: Upon completion of the process to alter the non-urban land usage, there is an obligation to remit a service fee in the amount of NTD 1 million (NB: one million only), payable by the client.
